<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XXXV. THE PYNNERES (AND PAYNTERS). Crucifixio Cristi. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor

[Scene, Golgotha, afterwards Mount Calvary.] 1. i Miles. Sir knyghtis, take heede hydir in hye, This dede on-dergh we may noght drawe, ?ee wootte youre selffe als wele as I, Howe lordis and leders of owre lawe Has geven dome Ã¾at Ã¾is doote schall dye. ii Mil. Sir, alle Ã¾are counsaile wele we knawe, Sen we are comen to Caluarie, Latte ilke man helpe nowe as hym awe. iii Mil. We are all redy, loo, Ãat forward to fullfille. iv Mil. Late here howe we schall doo, And go we tyte Ã¾er tille. 2. i Mil. It may no?t helpe her for to hone, If we schall any worshippe wynne. ii Mil. He muste be dede nedelyngis by none. iii Mil. Ãan is goode tyme Ã¾at we begynne. iv Mil. Late dynge hym doune, Ã¾an is he done, He schall nought dere vs with his dynne. i Mil. He schall be sette and lerned sone, With care to hym and all his kynne. ii Mil. Ãe foulest dede of all Shalle he dye for his dedis. iii Mil. That menes crosse hym we schall. iv Mil. Behalde so right he redis. 3. i Mil. Thanne to Ã¾is werke vs muste take heede, So Ã¾at oure wirkyng be noght wronge. ii Mil. None othir noote to neven is nede, But latte vs haste hym for to hange. iii Mil. And I haue gone for gere, goode speede, Bothe hammeres and nayles large and lange. iv Mil. Ãanne may we boldely do Ã¾is dede, Commes on, late kille Ã¾is traitoure strange. i Mil. Faire myght ?e falle in feere, Ãat has wrought on Ã¾is wise. ii Mil. Vs nedis nought for to lere, Suche faitoures to chastise. 4. iii Mil. Sen ilke a thyng es right arrayed, The wiselier nowe wirke may we, iv Mil. Ãe crosse on grounde is goodely graied, And boorede even as it awith to be. i Mil. Lokis Ã¾at Ã¾e ladde on lengthe be layde, And made me Ã¾ane vnto Ã¾is tree. ii Mil. For alle his fare he schalle be flaied, That one assaie sone schalle ye see. iii Mil. Come forthe, Ã¾ou cursed knave, Thy comforte sone schall kele. iv Mil. Thyne hyre here schall Ã¾ou haue. i Mil. Walkes oon, now wirke we wele. 5. Jesus. Almyghty god, my Fadir free, Late Ã¾is materes be made in mynde, Ãou badde Ã¾at I schulde buxsome be, For Adam plyght for to be pyned. Here to dede I obblisshe me Fro Ã¾at synne for to saue mankynde, And soueraynely be-seke I Ã¾e, That Ã¾ai for me may fauoure fynde; And fro Ã¾e fende Ã¾ame fende, So Ã¾at Ã¾er saules be saffe, In welthe withouten ende; I kepe nought ellis to craue. 6. i Mil. We! herke, sir knyghtis, for mahoundis bloode! Of Adam-kynde is all his Ã¾oght. ii Mil. Ãe warlowe waxis werre Ã¾an woode, Ãis doulfull dede ne dredith he noght. iii Mil. Ãou schulde haue mynde, with mayne and moode, Of wikkid werkis Ã¾at Ã¾ou haste wrought. iv Mil. I hope Ã¾at he had bene as goode Haue sesed of sawes Ã¾at he vppe sought. i Mil. Thoo sawes schall rewe hym sore For all his saunteryng sone. ii Mil. Ille spede Ã¾ame Ã¾at hym spare Tille he to dede be done! 7. iii Mil. Haue done belyue, boy, and make Ã¾e boune, And bende Ã¾i bakke vn-to Ã¾is tree. [Jesus lies down. iv Mil. Byhalde, hym-selffe has laide hym doune, In lenghe and breede as he schulde bee. i Mil. This traitoure here teynted of treasoune, Gose faste and fette hym Ã¾an, ?e thre. And sen he claymeth kyngdome with croune, Even as a kyng here haue schall hee. ii Mil. Nowe, certis, I schall no?t feyne Or his right hande be feste. iii Mil. Ãe lefte hande Ã¾anne is myne, Late see who beres hym beste. 8. iv Mil. Hys lymmys on lenghe Ã¾an schalle I lede, And even vnto Ã¾e bore Ã¾ame bringe, i Mil. Vnto his heede I schall take hede, And with myne hande helpe hym to hyng. ii Mil. Nowe sen we foure schall do Ã¾is dede, And medill with Ã¾is vnthrifty thyng, Late no man spare for speciall speede, Tille Ã¾at we haue made endyng. iii Mil. Ãis forward may not faile, Nowe are we right arraiede. iv Mil. This boy here in oure baile Shall bide full bittir brayde. 9. i Mil. Sir knyghtis, saie, howe wirke we nowe? ii Mil. ?is, certis, I hope I holde Ã¾is hande. iii Mil. And to Ã¾e boore I haue it brought, Full boxumly with-outen bande. ? iv Mil. Strike on Ã¾an harde, for hym Ã¾e boght. ? i Mil. ?is, here is a stubbe will stiffely stande, Thurgh bones and senous it schall be soght. This werke is well, I will warande. ii Mil. Saie, sir, howe do we Ã¾ore, Ãis bargayne may not blynne. iii Mil. It failis a foote and more, Ã¾e senous are so gone ynne. 10. iv Mil. I hope Ã¾at marke a-misse be bored. ii Mil. Ãan muste he bide in bittir bale. iii Mil. In faith, it was ouere skantely scored; Ãat makis it fouly for to faile. i Mil. Why carpe ?e so? faste on a corde, And tugge hym to, by toppe and taile. iii Mil. ?a, Ã¾ou comaundis lightly as a lorde, Come helpe to haale, with ille haile. i Mil. Nowe certis Ã¾at schall I doo, Full suerly as a snayle. iii Mil. And I schall tacche hym too, Full nemely with a nayle. 11. Ãis werke will holde, Ã¾at dar I heete, For nowe are feste faste both his handis. iv Mil. Go we all foure Ã¾anne to his feete, So schall oure space be spedely spende. ii Mil. Latte see, what bourde his bale myght beete, Tharto my bakke nowe wolde I bende. iv Mil. Owe! Ã¾is werke is all vnmeete, This boring muste all be amende. i Mil. A! pees man, for mahounde, Latte noman wotte Ã¾at wondir, A roope schall rugge hym doune, Yf all his synnous go a-soundre. 12. ii Mil. Ãat corde full kyndely can I knytte, Ãe comforte of Ã¾is karle to kele. i Mil. Feste on Ã¾anne faste Ã¾at all be fytte, It is no force howe felle he feele. ii Mil. Lugge on ?e both a litill ?itt. iii Mil. I schalle nought sese, as I haue seele. iv Mil. And I schall fonde hym for to hitte. ii Mil. Owe, haylle! iv Mil. Hoo nowe, I halde it wele. i Mil. Haue done, dryue in Ã¾at nayle, So Ã¾at no faute be foune. iv Mil. Ãis wirkyng wolde no?t faile, Yf foure bullis here were boune. 13. i Mil. Ther cordis haue evill encressed his paynes, Or he wer tille Ã¾e booryngis brought. ii Mil. ?aa, assoundir are both synnous and veynis, On ilke a side, so haue we soughte. iii Mil. Nowe all his gaudis no thyng hym gaynes, His sauntering schall with bale be bought. iv Mil. I wille goo saie to oure soueraynes Of all Ã¾is werkis howe we haue wrought. i Mil. Nay sirs, a nothir thyng Fallis firste to youe me, I badde we schulde hym hyng, On heghte Ã¾at men myght see. 14. ii. Mil. We woote wele so ther wordes wore, But sir, Ã¾at dede will do vs dere. i Mil. It may not mende for to moote more, Ãis harlotte muste be hanged here. ii Mil. The mortaise is made fitte Ã¾erfore. iii Mil. Feste on youre fyngeres Ã¾an, in feere. iv Mil. I wene it wolle neuere come Ã¾ore. We foure rayse it no?t right, to yere. i Mil. Say man, whi carpis Ã¾ou soo? Thy liftyng was but light. ii Mil. He menes Ã¾er muste be moo To heve hym vppe on hight. 15. iii Mil. Now certis, I hope it schall noght nede To calle to vs more companye. Me-thynke we foure schulde do Ã¾is dede, And bere hym to ?one hille on high. i Mil. It muste be done, with-outen drede, Nomore, but loke ?e be redy; And Ã¾is parte schalle I lifte and leede, On lenghe he schalle no lenger lie. Therfore nowe makis you boune, Late bere hym to ?one hill. iv Mil. Thanne will I bere here doune, And tente his tase vntill. 16. ii Mil. We twoo schall see tille aythir side, For ellis Ã¾is werke will wrie all wrang. iii Mil. We are redy, in Gode, sirs, abide, And late me first his fete vp fang. ii Mil. Why tente ?e so to tales Ã¾is tyde? i Mil. Lifte vppe! [All lift the cross together. iv Mil. Latte see! ii Mil. Owe! lifte a-lang. iii Mil. Fro all Ã¾is harme he schulde hym hyde, And he war God. iv Mil. Ãe deuill hym hang! i Mil. For grete harme haue I hente, My schuldir is in soundre. ii Mil. And sertis I am nere schente, So lange haue I borne vndir. 17. iii Mil. This crosse and I in twoo muste twynne, Ellis brekis my bakke in sondre sone. iv Mil. Laye doune agayne and leue youre dynne, Ãis dede for vs will neuere be done. [They lay it down.] i Mil. Assaie, sirs, latte se yf any gynne, May helpe hym vppe, with-outen hone; For here schulde wight men worschippe wynne, And noght with gaudis al day to gone. ii Mil. More wighter men Ã¾an we Full fewe I hope ?e fynde. iii Mil. Ãis bargayne will noght bee, For certis me wantis wynde. 18. iv Mil. So wille of werke neuere we wore, I hope Ã¾is carle some cautellis caste. ii Mil. My bourdeyne satte me wondir soore, Vnto Ã¾e hill I myght noght laste. i Mil. Lifte vppe, and sone he schall be Ã¾ore, Therfore feste on youre fyngeres faste. iii Mil. Owe, lifte! [They take up the cross again. i Mil. We, loo! iv Mil. A litill more. ii Mil. Holde Ã¾anne! i Mil. Howe nowe! ii Mil. Ãe werste is paste. iii Mil. He weyes a wikkid weght. ii Mil. So may we all foure saie, Or he was heued on heght, And raysed in Ã¾is array. 19. iv Mil. He made vs stande as any stones, So boustous was he for to bere. i Mil. Nowe raise hym nemely for Ã¾e nonys, And sette hym be Ã¾is mortas heere. And latte hym falle in alle at ones, For certis Ã¾at payne schall haue no pere. iii Mil. Heue vppe! iv Mil. Latte doune, so all his bones Are a-soundre nowe on sides seere. [The cross is reared.] i Mil. Ãis fallyng was more felle, Ã¾an all the harmes he hadde, Nowe may a man wele telle, Ãe leste lith of Ã¾is ladde. 20. iii Mil. Me thynkith Ã¾is crosse will noght abide, Ne stande stille in Ã¾is mo[r]teyse ?itt. iv Mil. Att Ã¾e firste tyme was it made ouere wyde, Ãat makis it wave, Ã¾ou may wele witte. i Mil. Itt schall be sette on ilke a side, So Ã¾at it schall no forther flitte, Goode wegges schall we take Ã¾is tyde, And feste Ã¾e foote, Ã¾anne is all fitte. ii Mil. Here are wegges arraied For Ã¾at, both grete and smale. iii Mil. Where are oure hameres laide, Ã¾at we schulde wirke with all? 21. iv Mil. We haue Ã¾em here euen atte oure hande. ii Mil. Gyffe me Ã¾is wegge, I schall it in dryue. iv Mil. Here is anodir ?itt ordande. iii Mil. Do take it me hidir belyue. i Mil. Laye on Ã¾anne faste. iii Mil. ?is, I warrande. I thryng Ã¾ame same, so motte I thryve. Nowe will Ã¾is crosse full stabely stande, All yf he raue Ã¾ei will noght ryve. i Mil. Say, sir, howe likis Ã¾ou nowe, Ãis werke Ã¾at we haue wrought? iv Mil. We praye youe sais vs howe, ?e fele, or faynte ?e ought? 22. Jesus. Al men Ã¾at walkis by waye or strete, Takes tente ?e schalle no trauayle tyne, By-holdes myn heede, myn handis, and my feete, And fully feele nowe or ?e fyne, Yf any mournyng may be meete Or myscheue mesured vnto myne. My Fadir, Ã¾at alle bales may bete, For-giffis Ã¾es men Ã¾at dois me pyne. What Ã¾ai wirke wotte Ã¾ai noght, Therfore my Fadir I craue Latte neuere Ã¾er synnys be sought, But see Ã¾er saules to saue. 23. i Mil. We! harke! he jangelis like a jay. ii Mil. Me thynke he patris like a py. iii Mil. He has ben doand all Ã¾is day, And made grete meuyng of mercy. iv Mil. Es Ã¾is Ã¾e same Ã¾at gune vs say, That he was Goddis sone almyghty? i Mil. Therfore he felis full felle affraye, And demyd Ã¾is day for to dye. ii Mil. Vah! qui destruis templum. iii Mil. His sawes wer so, certayne. iv Mil. And sirs, he saide to some He myght rayse it agayne. 24. i Mil. To mustir Ã¾at he hadde no myght, For all the kautelles Ã¾at he couthe kaste, All yf he wer in worde so wight, For all his force nowe he is feste. Als Pilate demed is done and dight, Therfore I rede Ã¾at we go reste. ii Mil. Ãis race mon be rehersed right, Thurgh Ã¾e worlde Ã¾oth este and weste. iii Mil. ?aa, late hym hynge here stille, And make mowes on Ã¾e mone. iv Mil. Ãanne may we wende at wille. i Mil. Nay goode sirs, noght so sone. 25. For certis vs nedis anodir note, Ãis kirtill wolde I of you craue. ii Mil. Nay, nay, sir, we will loke be lotte, Whilke of vs foure fallis to to haue. iii Mil. I rede we drawe cutte for Ã¾is coote, Loo, se howe sone alle sidis to saue. iv Mil. The schorte cutte schall wynne, Ã¾at wele ?e woote, Whedir itt falle to knyght or knave. i Mil. Felowes, ?e thar noght flyte, For this mantell is myne. ii Mil. Goo we Ã¾anne hense tyte, Ãis trauayle here we tyne.
